channel.title: Need to learn C/C++
channel.description:
Over the next few weeks I need to learn c and cpp.
Ive been using Java and PHP for a while now, and i've recently started to use python for many of my projects, but I now need to learn C/c++ etc and portability over lunix mac and windows etc. I'm quite a competent programmer if that helps.
Where can I start? some online tutorials I can print tomorrow would be good.

[quote=“hrach123, post:19, topic:389937”]You should try and start learning from the basics, if you fully understand the basics you should slowly move on. I hope that Herpes :)[/quote]So do i

item.title: Need to learn C/C++
item.dc:creator: @pkedpker pkedpker
item.description:
@pkedpker wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:6, topic:389937”][quote author=la­wl link=topic=485846.msg3560664#msg3560664 date=1302231664]
i dont think you can learn c in a few weeks
[/quote]
I disagree with this. C is a small language feature-wise compared to others.
You probably won’t be writing very large/usable applications for a while though.[/quote]

yup this… C has a very short command set not much to learn, if you already know the syntax of PHP/Java your pretty much 50% or more into C and pretty much most of the commands and datatypes match that up of java like ints/voids/functions not much that you really cannot know.

But a huge part of C/C++ is assembly which I suggest learning first, it will benefit your mind by absorbing pointers and addresses part of C/C++ much more efficient so you won’t be going to tutorial sites trying to find out what are pointers because you are unsure.

What i’m trying to get at here… if I never seen something like this.

MOV EAX,DWORD PTR DS:[14C4494]
or
MOV DWORD PTR DS:[14C4494],EAX

I probably would have struggled with pointers and addresses and all that crap.

But now when I look at something like this

int a = *(DWORD *)Pointer; //0x14C4494

I would see right away that, that above is just you accessing the pointer offset at 0x14C4494 and getting the first 4 bytes out.

then you can start to get clever and learn nicer things you can do stuff like

When you reverse engineer, or do alot of crackme’s you can easily convert

Lets make this as simple as possible so a little legend, 0xC = 12.

So we got.
MOV EAX,DWORD PTR DS:[14C4494+0xC]
to

you wish it would be this simple.
char* Pointer;
Pointer = 0x14C4494; //nope this won’t work, read about it below.
int EAX = *(DWORD *)Pointer+12;

but yeah… the makers of C/C++ fucked up a little and you have to do…
char* Pointer;
Pointer = (DWORD*) 0x14C4494;

//you have to try to keep it (DWORD *) because you are trying to put a address which is 4 bytes… not (WORD *) or (BYTE ) which use address of 2 bytes long or 1 byte long. I’ll tell you like this 99.9% of the time when you deal with addresses they will be 4 bytes. I rarely seen the addresses being shorter, but I don’t got a 64bit cpu idk if the addresses there are 8 bytes or not… if they are then it may not work on 64bit cpus you may have to program like
[b]Pointer = (QWORD)0x14C4494;[/b]

But I doubt they wouldn’t fix this on 64bit cpus probably they automatically convert your 32 bit programs to run on 64bit so don’t worry stick to (DWORD *) when you trying to make a pointer point to some address.

or in one line.
char* Pointer = (DWORD*)0x14C4494;
int EAX = *(DWORD *)Pointer+12;

You may be thinking why does
b0x14C4494; [/b]
and
*(DWORD *)Pointer+12;

why does the first one not have a star in front
and second one has a star in front…

because the star in front of variable/datatype represents the value! and no star represents address.

now EAX is 4 bytes from pointer+12 offset. like
00 01 02 03 04 05 06 07 08 09 0A 0B [0C 0D 0E 0F] 10

Also I forgot to say but the array above with starts at 00 01… the 00 is actually at RAM array element 0x14C4494. Thats pretty much why assembly makes pointers so easy to understand because of the [] brackets in the syntax of the assembly snippet above.

So pretty much
00 01 02 03 04 05 06 07 08 09 0A 0B [0C 0D 0E 0F] 10
I would like to see in like
14C4494 00 01 02 03 04 05 06 07 08 09 0A 0B [0C 0D 0E 0F] 10

thats how you see it in a dump view like in ollydebgger, any dump analyzer or hex editor the address shows in front of maybe 16 bytes per address sometimes up to 32 bytes per line they try to keep it in 8 byte increments.

You may still not understand it, but think of
00 as being at memory offset of 0x14C4494
01 as being at memory offset of 0x14C4495
02 as being at memory offset of 0x14C4496
etc…
we picked out 0C 0D 0E 0F, because
0C as being at memory offset of 0x14C4494+0xC

and of course DWORD means datatype of 32 bits aka 4 bytes.

the value will be switched in endianness of course. Not sure why this happens but all research points to what kind of CPU you got.

so 0C 0D 0E 0F will actually be 0F 0E 0D 0C on my computer.

or in better sense… just a address with no pointers!
int EAX = *(DWORD *)0x14C4494 + 0xC; // or just 0x14C44A0

oh yah when you look at assembly for so long you start writing in hexadecimal rofl.

so much little skills which you pick up along the way which make you into a good programmer/hacker.

You would normally just see examples like this

char* blah = NULL;
blah = new char[10];

now you’ll get all over your head because you’ll get confused with symbols to transform pointers such as.

&blah, *blah or just blah.

but with that assembly above you can easily clear your mind of any assumptions what each of those symbols mean and truly be SURE, meh i’m just a little high right now rofl.

Lets get back to this.

MOV EAX,DWORD PTR DS:[14C4494]
or
MOV DWORD PTR DS:[14C4494],EAX

obviously without even knowing assembly you would look at DS:[] and think of a array, which is not bad way of seeing it, actually thats how I see it everyday

Now with that being said check this out… say that really is a HUGE array and element at 0x14C4494 must have some value AM I RIGHT? yes.

thats all pointers and addresses really are… pointers are addresses that point at a specific value or… they may be pointers that point to another pointer which points to another and so on and so on…

now why are addresses and pointers so alike? because addresses… point to values! yes sir addresses are in a sense pointers.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @chri5 chri5
item.description:
@chri5 wrote:

Mopman:

What takes time to learn is not C itself, but concepts of software engineering that you were previously sheltered from if you’ve only used Java and PHP.

Which is exactly why I want to learn c, so I can understand/learn these concepts.

la­wl:

i dont think you can learn c in a few weeks

To start in the next few weeks and learn properly over a while…

Read full topic

item.title: Need to learn C/C++
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

In the “K&R” book they also start off by giving you small tools and ask you to write (complicated) programs. You have to read it, literally, word-for-word.

Read full topic

item.title: Need to learn C/C++
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

K&R is really good, but the reason why it’s so short is that much of it is stuff that a language lawyer loves i.e. many sentences have far reaching consequences. As a side-effect, it’s regarded as an authoritative text. The authors did a good job of masking complexity by leaving it up to the reader to understand the full implications of things which is why you get so many rave reviews… if you have experience writing proofs, then you’ll understand what i’m saying. And yes, I’ve read it cover to cover.

That being said, I’d recommend C Primer Plus by Stephen Prata… there’s a reason why it’s nearly 5X as long as The C Programming Language.

Read full topic

item.description:
